title: Guide
description:
REC’s Academy provides a practical settlement guide to help international students preparing to study in Korea,

or those who have just arrived, quickly access essential information for daily life and smooth academic adjustment.

Is it possible to enter

a Korean university without TOPIK?
links.description:
Studying in Korea without TOPIK is possible,

links.title:
Studying in Korea

Where should I start?
links.description:
A step-by-step guide for international students starting

their study-abroad journey in Korea.

section1.text1:
If you are considering studying abroad in Korea,

one of the most common questions you will encounter is:

Is TOPIK (Test of Proficiency in Korean) really necessary?
section1.text2:
For students who are new to the Korean language,

high TOPIK score requirements can feel daunting.
section1.text3:
However, with the expansion of English-taught programs, conditional admissions,

and language linked pathways,

it is increasingly possible to study in Korea without TOPIK,

depending on your chosen university and major.
section1.text4: In this guide, REC’s Academy explains:

eligibility.q: Are There Universities You Can Enter Without TOPIK?
eligibility.title: Many Korean universities operate admission processes for international students that <semibold>do not require TOPIK at the time of application,</semibold> or that evaluate applicants based on alternative criteria.

display.title: TOPIK may not be required for:
list: Programs where admissions focus more on:

eligibility.footerText:
In such cases, TOPIK is not a prerequisite for admission.

REC’s Academy helps students identify universities and majors where TOPIK is not initially required

and where admission pathways are realistic.

english.q: Admission process based on English proficiency
english.title:
Many Korean universities offer English-taught degree programs

and accept internationally recognized English test scores, such as:
english.footerText: In some cases, students from <semibold>English-speaking countries</semibold> may be exempt from English proficiency requirements. REC’s Academy evaluates each student’s English level and matches them with suitable English-based programs.

conditional.title: If you do not have TOPIK but wish to enroll in a Korean-taught degree program, you may apply through:

items.title: Admission is granted on the condition that the student achieves a required Korean level within a specified period.
Students first enroll in a <semibold>university-affiliated Korean language institute.</semibold>
After reaching the required level, they transition into a degree program.
Entry to Korea on a <semibold>D-4 (language) visa</semibold>

conditional.footerText: REC’s Academy explains these options clearly and helps students plan <semibold>realistic timelines.</semibold>

topik.q: Are There TOPIK Requirements After Admission?
topik.title:
Even if TOPIK is not required for admission, some universities require TOPIK for graduation.

Common graduation-related requirements include:
list: Submission of a TOPIK score (often <semibold>Level 4 or higher</semibold>)
Completion of mandatory Korean language courses

footerDisplay.title: Important
footerDisplay.description:
Always check graduation requirements, not just admission conditions.

REC’s Academy reviews both admission and graduation language requirements before students apply.

considerations.q: Things to Consider When Choosing a university
considerations.title: If you plan to apply without TOPIK, carefully check:
list: Does the university operate a <semibold>language institute</semibold>?
Are language requirements clearly stated in official guidelines?

footerDisplay.title: Note
footerDisplay.description: Language requirements may vary by major. Programs in <semibold>arts, design, and physical education</semibold> often have more flexible standards than theory-heavy majors.

section3.title: Conclusion
section3.description: Studying in Korea <semibold>without TOPIK is possible,</semibold> but it requires <semibold>strategic planning.</semibold>

list.title:
Students can successfully enter Korean universities even without prior Korean language certification.

REC’s Academy supports students by:
items: Providing structured, compliant, and transparent guidance

section3.description2:
There are many ways to open the door to studying in Korea.

The most important step is choosing the path that fits you best.

section1.text1:
If you are considering studying abroad in Korea, you may wonder where to begin.

Admission requirements, language preparation, visas,

and university selection can feel overwhelming at first.
section1.text2:
This guide provides a step-by-step starting point

for international students, especially from Africa and Central Asia,

who are beginning their study-abroad planning.

university.title: How should I choose a university?
university.footerText: If your TOPIK level is not sufficient, English-taught or language-linked pathways may be more suitable.

preparation.title: Recommended Preparation Order
preparation.footerText: This process typically takes <semibold>3-6 months or longer,</semibold> depending on circumstances.

section3.title: Final note
section3.description:
Studying in Korea is not just an application, it is a life transition into a new academic and cultural environment.

Start step by step, based on what you can prepare now.
